**23rd of Scorched Skies, 432nd Cycle**

The Great Aching has subsided for now. The warmth of the mouth of the mountains eases the throbbing in my bones. It was‚Ä¶ curious, this one. A small, hairless creature, speaking the sing-song language of the frozen north. He called himself ‚ÄúDmitri.‚Äù

Dmitri claimed to be a ‚Äúgeologist,‚Äù whatever that is. He babbled on about rocks and minerals, their strange names rolling off his tongue like pebbles sprung from a rushing stream. He smelled of pine and smoke, and beneath that, a hint of metal, sharp and strange.

He didn‚Äôt flinch when I spoke. Most shrink back, whimpering, their scent turning sour with fear. Dmitri, though, he only grinned, those white teeth gleaming in the flickering light of the lava pits. He even dared to touch the obsidian scales on my snout, his hand cool against the heated surface.

He asked of my hoard, of course, as mortals are wont to do. I humored him, spinning tales of ancient jewels and gleaming metals, each whispered word a barb of truth, each glittering illusion concealing my true treasures: the wisdom woven into the smoke-stained rocks
